work.p: As rendered by earlier editors, the manuscript is written as aphoristic fragments connected by ellipses, in the manner of the preface to the first edition of Leaves of Grass (1855). The thought is similar to this line from the preface: "The poetic quality is not marshalled in rhyme or uniformity or abstract addresses to things nor in melancholy complaints or good precepts, but is the life of these and much else and is in the soul" (1855, p. v).

titleStmt.title: One obligation of great fresh
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

notesStmt.note: Because the manuscript has not been located it is difficult to speculate on the circumstances or date of its composition. The discussion of "the poetic quality" and the punctuation (at least as rendered by earlier editors) are similar to the 1855 Preface to Leaves of Grass, so it is possible that the composition date was before or early in 1855.

biblStruct.note: Grier based his text on Notes and Fragments, ed. Richard Maurice Bucke (London, Ontario: A. Talbot & Co., printers, 1899), 124.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: One Obligation
bibl.orgName: The location of this manuscript is unknown.

revisionDesc.change: reconciled with EAD record; added Work ID
checked, added date to bibl (from finding aid information)

body.p: One obligation of great fresh bards remains . . . the clink of words is empty and offensive . . . the poetic quality blooms simple and earnest as the laws of the world.
The audible rhyme soon nauseates . . . the inaudible rhyme is delicious without end.
